story.text:
> [Code review], according to a 2016 article published in Empirical Software Engineering, actually works. But we can't stake our team’s success on just "more code reviews."

See [[Code Review Impacts Quality]]

> The 2008 book Patient Safety and Quality: An Evidence-Based Handbook for Nurses states that sleep-deprived nurses make more serious mistakes, full stop. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK2645/ link]

> The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a part of the CDC, has shown that stressed nurses are both significantly less productive and significantly more likely to make serious mistakes.

See [[CDC: STRESS...at Work]]
I subscribe to the view that human error is a marker of a failed investigation. See [[Usefulness of Error]]
So these references leaning on nursing mistakes make me suspicious of the underlying research even if I generally agree with the direction the author is going with their argument.

The first quote didn't bug me at all. Code review may be my favorite example where software industry has accepted a practice on faith without our usual dogma about metrics and measurement. So this quote made me wanna look more closely at the research.

item.text: I liked this article, but there were a couple ways the author phrased things when referencing some research that bugged me. Piqued my interest enough to follow some links.

[Code review], according to a 2016 article published in Empirical Software Engineering, actually works. But we can't stake our team’s success on just "more code reviews." See [[Code Review Impacts Quality]]
This first quote didn't bug me at all. Code review is a great example where software industry has accepted a practice without our usual dogma about metrics and measurement.

> [Code review], according to a 2016 article published in Empirical Software Engineering, actually works. But we can't stake our team’s success on just "more code reviews." See [[Code Review Impacts Quality]]

See [[Code Review Impacts Quality]]

See [[Code Review Impacts Quality]]

See [[Code Review Impacts Quality]]

> The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a part of the CDC, has shown that stressed nurses are both significantly less productive and significantly more likely to make serious mistakes. [ link]

See [[CDC: STRESS...at Work]]

I subscribe to the view that human error is a marker of a failed investigation. So these phrases leaning on nursing mistakes make me suspicious of the underlying research even if I generally agree with the direction the author is going with their argument.

This first quote didn't bug me at all. Code review may be my favorite example where software industry has accepted a practice on faith without our usual dogma about metrics and measurement. So this quote made me wanna look more closely at the research. See [[Usefulness of Error]]
